meanings.definition: A person who makes slow progress and falls behind others.
meanings.sent1: The laggard in the race struggled to keep up with the rest of the runners.
meanings.sent2: The teacher encouraged the laggard student to work harder to catch up with the class.
meanings.sent3: The laggard finally finished the project, but everyone else had already moved on to the next assignment.
meanings.sent4: The laggard in the group was like a turtle trying to compete with hares.
meanings.sent5: Being a laggard can be frustrating when you always feel like you're behind.

meanings.sent1: The laggard snail made its way across the garden at a leisurely pace.
meanings.sent2: The laggard progress of the construction project caused delays in the schedule.
meanings.sent3: The laggard sloth seemed perfectly content to take its time in everything it did.
meanings.sent4: The laggard growth of the plant made the gardener wonder if it needed more sunlight.
meanings.sent5: The laggard pace of the old car made it difficult to keep up with traffic.
